title: What made Cleopatra so desirable? - Quora

response.answer_text: First off, who was Cleopatra?  She was of royal blood. Not only that, but her family was associated with Alexander the Great, a figure that many Romans admired and some even worshiped. Cleopatra was said to be charming and attractive. Of course, she wasn’t a great beauty, but she certainly wasn’t ugly and managed to attract two of the most powerful and desirable men of her age. Let’s see why. Look the people she attracted. The two most famous examples are Julius Caesar and Mark Anthony, both men that desired power and influence. Cleopatra forged political alliances with both, as she was a woman and thus, not the first-in-line for the throne. She was married to her brother, Ptolemy, who was to be the ruling pharaoh of Egypt. Caesar was a ladies man that had a large number of mistresses, including women from notable families. Cleopatra was just one of them. He probably desired to have the ruler of Egypt be loyal to him, personally, rather than to just be a successor, like Ptolemy was. It’s also possible Caesar disliked Ptolemy due to the death of Pompey Magnus. Here, we reach a strange fork in the road. Caesar was in his 50s when he died. We can’t know what his plans were. Would he create the Roman empire in the same way Augustus did or simply retire, like Sulla? Maybe being the de-facto ruler of Egypt would be a good retirement plan. Caesar’s child with Cleopatra could prove to be a good heir, the rightful heir to both the throne of Egypt and Caesar’s fortune and position in Roman society. Mark Anthony was a different beast. With Octavian being the heir to Caesar’s fortune and name, Mark Anthony’s future was left uncertain. He fled to Egypt and made an alliance with Cleopatra, who by then had Caesar’s biological son. The civil war between Octavian and Anthony couldn’t have been won without the support of Egypt. It’s important to note that a big chunk of the Senate supported Mark Anthony over Octavian. Anthony was a proven general and a more experienced man, but no match for Octavian and Agrippa. Also, Anthony claimed Octavian was not the legitimate heir to Caesar’s name or fortune, naming Cleopatra’s son with Caesar the actual heir. That didn’t please Octavian, but it certainly pleased Cleopatra. If Anthony won, he would be the step-father of Caesar’s heir and the most powerful man in Rome, which would make Cleopatra not only the queen of Egypt, but potentially the empress of all Rome. Not bad when you think about it and certainly enough of a reason to make Anthony desire a relationship with her. In the end, both Cleopatra and her son were killed by Octavian, who became the first Roman emperor.
